origination.corpname: Carnegie Corporation of New York. Aging Society Project (1982-1986)

did.unittitle: Carnegie Corporation of New York. Aging Society Project (1982-1986) records 1982-1986
did.abstract: Project established to study the public policy implications of an aging society. Administrative files, largely of project director D. Lydia Bronte, including subject files, name files, publication records, and conference files.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

did.physloc: Portions located in offsite storage; prior notification required for access.

acqinfo.p: This record group forms part of the Michigan Historical Collection / Institute of Gerontology Joint Archives in Gerontology (donor no. 6160)

accessrestrict.p: The record group is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Carnegie Corporation of New York. Aging Society Project (1982-1986) records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The Aging Society Project was an inquiry into the public policy implications of an aging society. It originated in the Spring of 1982, when Alan Pifer, the outgoing president of the Carnegie Corporation, began to explore the significance of demographic changes in the United States during the previous thirty years. He commissioned two preliminary studies, by Michael Teitelbaum and D. Lydia Bronte, which pointed to the need for a more thorough study on the issues of aging.

In December 1982, the Carnegie Corporation approved funding for a one-year planning phase for the Aging Project, which was to be chaired by Alan Pifer and directed by D. Lydia Bronte. They began to familiarize themselves with the literature of the field, to build a small library and to acquaint themselves with the leading scholars in the field.

Beginning in February 1983, the project sponsored a series of Conferences dealing with the economic, political, social and ethical implications of the Aging American Society. These Conferences also dealt with particular segments of the American Society, such as women, Blacks and Hispanics.

In November of 1983 discussions began with the American Academy of Arts and Sciences for publication of a Collection of essays on aging in an issue of their journal Daedalus. For the remainder of 1983 and 1984, the project staff prepared for the book of essays, met with the essay authors in June 1984, convened additional conferences on aging, and visited Sweden, which has one of the oldest populations in the world.
On February 11-14, 1986 the Aging Society Project held its last Conference, in Japan, entitled "Population Aging in the United States and Japan: National and International Implications."

In the Winter 1986 issue of Daedalus, "The Aging Society" was published. This Collection of essays was also issued with additional articles and in a different form by W.W. Norton and Company under the title Our Aging Society: Paradox and Promise on May 19, 1986. Shortly, after the completion of this book the Aging Society Project ended. The records of the project were donated by D. Lydia Bronte to the University of Michigan's Institute of Gerontology. After processing, this material was transferred to the Michigan Historical Collections/Institute of Gerontology's Joint Archives in Gerontology located in the Bentley Historical Library, Ann Arbor, Michigan.

scopecontent.p: The Aging Society Project of the Carnegie Corporation of New York record group consists of administrative files, largely of project director D. Lydia Bronte, including subject files, name files, publication records, and conference files. The records have been divided into five series: Subject File; Individuals File; Organization File; Book File; and Conference File.

controlaccess.head: Subjects:
controlaccess.subject: Aging.
Gerontology.
controlaccess.corpname: University of Michigan. Institute of Gerontology.

scopecontent.p: The Subject File, contained in boxes 1-2, covers the period 1982-1986. It includes correspondence, interviews, budget proposals, speeches, articles, lists and reports concerning administration of the project, and staff activities. Two major; portions of the material are D. Lydia Bronte's survey on aging, which familiarized her with the subject, and Bronte and Alan Pifer's trip to Sweden, where they studies aging in Europe's oldest society. The series is arranged alphabetically by subject.

scopecontent.p: The Individuals File, boxes 3-5, includes correspondence, conference presentations and articles by leaders in the field of aging. This material covers the period 1982-1986. It is arranged alphabetically by author or correspondent.

did.unittitle: Riley, Matilda White and John W. Riley 1982-1986

scopecontent.p: The Organization File, boxes 6-10, covers the period 1982-1986. The material includes correspondence, speeches and publications from and by organizations in the aging field, such as the American Association for the Advancement of Science, the Brookdale Center, Council on Foundations, Gerontological Society of America, and the National Council on Aging. This material is arranged alphabetically by title of organization.

scopecontent.p: The Book File, boxes 11-15, contains meeting summaries and transcripts, chapter drafts, correspondence, articles and book reviews. These papers concern advisory committee meetings, author conferences, drafts of individual chapters, the selection of a book agent and publisher, and book publicity. This file is arranged alphabetically by topic.

scopecontent.p: The Conference File, boxes 16-19, covers the period 1983-1984. It contains correspondence, notes, participants lists, summaries, transcripts, agendas, reports, proceedings and publications concerning the conferences sponsored by the Aging Society Project. The conferences cover aging as it affects women, children, Blacks, Hispanics, the labor force, education, and other societies. This material is arranged chronologically by conference and then alphabetically by topic. Records from the conference "Population Aging in the United States and Japan: National and International Implications" were not transferred as part of this accession of materials.
